importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous government shutdown that lasted 35 days and was the longest in history, beginning on December 22, 2018.
The end date of the longest government shutdown in history, which concluded on January 25, 2019, after 35 days of closure.
The date the article was updated, indicating the current government shutdown is ongoing as of this date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the previous longest government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and set a historical record.
The current government shutdown has not yet been resolved, and the article indicates it is still active as of October 21, 2025.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, lasted 35 days, making it the longest in nearly 50 years.
The 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office.
During the 2018 shutdown, approximately 800,000 people were employed at shuttered federal agencies, with about 300,000 furloughed and not paid.
A full government shutdown is currently underway due to the failure to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills.
The current shutdown is a full shutdown, unlike the 2018 event which was partial, allowing some agencies to remain operational.

Partisan divisions in Congress, especially under Republican Speaker Mike Johnson with a narrow House majority and lack of 60 votes to overcome a Senate filibuster, have made legislative compromise difficult.
Government shutdowns have become less common since 1990, with only six occurring since then, but political deadlock continues to pose a risk.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The subject of the shutdowns; the entity whose operations are suspended during funding gaps.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. government agency that provides budget and economic analysis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Credited with estimating the $3 billion economic loss from the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A date marking the start of a government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The beginning of the longest government shutdown in history, which lasted until January 25, 2019.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A date marking the end of a government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The conclusion of the 35-day shutdown, which was the longest in history at that time.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Currently leading a narrow House majority that lacks the votes to override a Senate filibuster, contributing to the political deadlock.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule in the U.S. Senate that requires 60 votes to end debate and pass legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Creates a barrier to passing funding legislation, making it difficult to avoid a shutdown despite bipartisan efforts.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal funding bills required to operate all branches of the government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass any of these bills is the direct cause of the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source and author of the article, providing updates and reporting on government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides additional reporting on which federal services are affected during the shutdown.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Year when the first federal government shutdown occurred
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Marks the earliest recorded shutdown in the modern era, according to CNN research.

namedEntities.name: 1980s
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Decade when federal agencies were first instructed to stop operations during funding lapses
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Indicates the formalization of shutdown protocols in U.S. government operations.

namedEntities.name: $3 billion
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Estimated economic loss from the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights the significant economic consequences of government shutdowns.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Number of people employed at shuttered federal agencies during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Shows the scale of human impact during a shutdown, with 300,000 furloughed.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Number of federal employees furloughed during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Illustrates the direct human and economic impact on workers during a shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government is currently in a full shutdown due to the failure to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This marks the first such shutdown in years, following a historic 35-day partial shutdown in December 2018 that cost the economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP and affected about 800,000 federal employees, with 300,000 furloughed. The current situation is complicated by deepening political divisions, with Republican Speaker Mike Johnson leading a narrow House majority and lacking the 60 votes needed to overcome a Senate filibuster. Since 1990, there have been only six government shutdowns, but partisan gridlock continues to prevent timely legislative action, highlighting a broader systemic challenge in U.S. governance.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
